filedesc.updatestmt:
The William Blake Archive is pleased to announce the publication of seventeen pen and ink drawings by Blake. Ranging chronologically from his apprenticeship as an engraver to the final decade of his life, this group offers a comprehensive overview of his work in the medium. Most were created when Blake was learning his craft as an artist and reveal his exploration of various themes and genres. His apprentice drawings for James Basire (The Body of Edward I and Countess Aveline) show his early engagement with medieval art. Another group (two drawings titled Figures from a Greek Vase and Charon) is clearly based on classical art or mythology, responses to which were central to British art and design in the second half of the eighteenth century. The cluster of related sketches on two leaves, each titled Four Composition Sketches, is the earliest extant example of Blake’s attempt to construct a pictorial narrative through a series of images. In these, he began to develop his own version of the sublime, an aesthetic more fully represented by the texts and designs in the illuminated books of the 1790s. Several works from the 1780s show the influence of neoclassicism and take their subjects from two fields of lasting interest to Blake: British history (King Alfred, A Woman Enthroned, and Procession of Monks) and the Bible (Saul and David, Goliath Cursing David, and two versions of The Good Farmer). The three much later drawings are exceptions to Blake’s customary procedures and subjects: a landscape Garden Path, The Prophet Isaiah drawn on a woodblock for a wood engraving never executed, and Lady Torrens, a copy of a family portrait by his friend and patron John Linnell.
Blake did not execute a large number of pen and ink drawings. This is a bit surprising, given the compatibility between the linearity of the medium and his insistence on “the distinct, sharp, and wirey ... bounding line” as the “great and golden rule of art” (Blake’s Descriptive Catalogue). He did, however, make extensive use of pen and ink work to outline forms in his water colors, color prints, and hand tinted relief etchings in the illuminated books. For preliminary sketching, Blake favored pencil over pen and ink, probably because of the lower cost of pencil and the ease of erasure and correction it offered. The Archive will publish his pencil sketches decade by decade, beginning with the earliest works, 1779 through 1790.
This is the first time that works from the Society of Antiquaries, London have been represented in the Archive. Accordingly, we are also publishing the Society's Blake collection list, which includes all of its original works by Blake, not just those published in the Archive, and joins the Collection Lists of over thirty other contributing institutions.
As always, the William Blake Archive is a free site, imposing no access restrictions and charging no subscription fees. The site is made possible by the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill with the University of Rochester, the continuing support of the Library of Congress, and the cooperation of the international array of libraries and museums that have generously given us permission to reproduce works from their collections in the Archive.

objdescid.compdate: c. 1821The dating is uncertain. A date of c. 1821 recommends itself because Blake's only published wood engravings appeared that year in Robert John Thornton's edition of The Pastorals of Virgil.

objinfo.support: wood blockThe wood grain appears as reddish-brown curving lines throughout the design. These are particularly noticeable above and to the right of the head of the central figure. There is also a brown flaw in the wood curving extending from the central figure's raised right wrist toward the right.

illustration.illusobjdesc: An illustration of the biblical narrative from the Book of Isaiah 29:1-6, this scene depicts a seated Isaiah in the foreground as the destruction of Jerusalem (called "Ariel" in the biblical passage) he foretells occurs in the background. Wearing a long gown with an unbuttoned collar, Isaiah sits facing forward on a stone with legs bent and both bare feet visible beneath his gown. He has long, curly hair and a beard; his mouth is open, suggesting he is speaking. His right arm is raised vertically, palm forward, and with his left, which is by his side, he points toward text written on a partially unfurled scroll. An area of radiance out of which beams of light extend encircles Isaiah's head. In the upper half of the scene, a castellated wall (presumably of Jerusalem) stretches the width of the drawing and flames appear both above and below it. At the left terminus of the wall, a group of soldiers (Romans in the narrative) face right. The closest of these sits atop a horse. A standing solider is visible to the right of the horse's head and the presence of at least six vertical pikes or spears suggests additional soldiers. At the right end of the wall, a group of figures, the first two a man and woman with arms raised vertically, appear to run rightward, as if fleeing from the soldiers. These are likely the Jews fleeing the destruction of Jerusalem.

component.illusobjdesc: An illustration of the biblical narrative from the Book of Isaiah 29:1-6, this scene depicts a seated Isaiah in the foreground as the destruction of Jerusalem he foretells occurs in the background. Wearing a long gown with an unbuttoned collar, Isaiah sits facing forward on a stone with legs bent and both bare feet visible beneath the serpentine folds of his gown. He has long, curly hair and a beard; his mouth is open, suggesting he is speaking. His right arm is raised vertically, palm out and vertical. With his left, which is by his side, he points toward text written on a partially unfurled scroll.
An area of radiance out of which beams of light extend encircles Isaiah's head.

With his left hand, Isaiah points to text on a partially unfurled scroll which rests on a stone lower right. Marks on the scroll may indicate Hebrew letters, although these do not constitute a legible text.
Isaiah sits on a large stone just above the bottom edge of the design. The scroll to the right also rests on a stone.
In the upper half of the scene, a castellated wall of Jerusalem (called Ariel in the biblical text illustrated) stretches the width of the drawing.

At the left terminus of the wall, a group of soldiers (Romans in the narrative) face right. The closest of these sits atop a horse with right leg bent and right arm raised horizontally, likely pointing toward the group of figures at right. A standing soldier is visible to the right of the horse's head and the presence of at least six vertical pikes or spears suggests additional soldiers.

The closest soldier in the group at upper left rides a horse that faces right. Although its rider extends his arm rightward, the animal leans in the opposite direction, away from the sprouting flames. Its mouth is open, giving it a fearful expression.
Although only two soldiers are visible in the upper left corner, the presence of at least six vertical pikes or spears suggests additional soldiers.

At the right end of the wall, a group of figures appear to run rightward, as if away from the soldiers. These are likely the Jews fleeing the destruction of Jerusalem. This group may be a family with a mother and father (center) and two children.

At the right end of the wall, a group of figures appear to run rightward, as if away from the soldiers. These are likely the Jews fleeing the destruction of Jerusalem. The first adult figure from the right, a nude male figure faces right but turns his head up to look left. His arms are raised vertically with palms facing up and fingers spread. With left leg bent at the knee and right extended backward, he appears to run or flee to the right. His mouth may be open. If the group of fleeing figures is a family, he is likely the father.

At the right end of the wall, a group of figures appear to run rightward, as if away from the soldiers. These are likely the Jews fleeing the destruction of Jerusalem. To the left of the nude male figure, a gowned female figure with long curly hair faces right but turns her head up to look left. Echoing the posture of her companion, her arms are raised vertically with palms facing up and fingers spread. Her right leg is bent and the knee and left extended backward as she runs or flees to the right. If the group of fleeing figures is a family, she is likely the mother.

At the right end of the wall, a group of figures appear to run rightward, as if away from the soldiers. These are likely the Jews fleeing the destruction of Jerusalem. The leftmost figure in this group is a child or adolescent who is positioned behind the adult female figure and thus only visible from the torso up. Like the two adults, the child appears to face right but turn its head up to look left. The figure appears to have short hair though the gender is indeterminate.

At the right end of the wall, a group of figures appear to run rightward, as if away from the soldiers. These are likely the Jews fleeing the destruction of Jerusalem. The rightmost figure in this group is a young child who, like the other figures in the group, faces right but turns its head up to look left. The child may have its left arm raised vertically and appears to run or flee right with one leg bent forward at the knee and the other extended backward.
